Diesel fuel.
Diesel fuel in general is any liquid fuel used in diesel engines, whose fuel ignition takes place, without any spark, as a result of compression of the inlet air mixture and then injection of fuel.
A bus (contracted from omnibus, with variants multibus, motorbus, autobus, etc.) is a road vehicle designed to carry many passengers.

Diesel is a fraction obtained from petroleum distillation, either as a distillate or a residue. Diesel engines have found broad use as a result of higher thermodynamic efficiency and thus fuel efficiency.

A diesel engine is an internal combustion engine that uses the heat of compression to initiate ignition to burn the fuel, which is injected into the combustion chamber during the final stage of compression.
Gasoline is a transparent, petroleum-derived liquid that is used primarily as a fuel in spark-ignited internal combustion engines.
